title: Mobile Money Interoperability & Competition Assessment in Ghana

semanticMatches.sourceTitle: Competition dynamics in mobile money markets in Tanzania

raw_json.fitSummary: Core DFS competition experts with decades of market conduct enforcement and settlement design.
fitPros: Secured a 90% USSD price reduction in Solving Kenya’s USSD pricing problem for digital financial services, unlocking market entry for new wallets.
Benchmarked interoperability and compliance regimes across corridors in Studying digital remittances from Malaysia to Philippines.
fitCons: Would require dedicated behavioural testing labs in Ghana to evidence consumer friction.

referenceProjects.title: Solving Kenya’s USSD pricing problem for digital financial services
referenceProjects.summary: Safaricom’s M-Pesa is a World and Kenyan market leader in mobile money. Working with Acacia Economics, we carried out a market inquiry for the Competition Authority of Kenya (CAK) into use of USSD channels for digital financial services. Our report found that Safaricom’s high USSD prices caused a margin squeeze for other digital financial service providers. With our support, the CAK negotiated a settlement with Safaricom under which it dropped its USSD prices by 90%, removing a vital barrier to competition in Kenyan digital financial services.

referenceProjects.title: Studying digital remittances from Malaysia to Philippines
referenceProjects.summary: Consultative Group to Assist the Poor (CGAP), a part of the World Bank Group, engaged us to study the regulatory conditions that have enabled the proliferation of remittance services across the Malaysia-Philippines corridor. Our findings include 10 recommendations for policymakers and regulators in other jurisdictions to promote development of non-bank remittance markets.

title: Infrastructure Sharing Roadmap for Liberia

semanticMatches.sourceTitle: Fostering cross-sector infrastructure sharing for broadband

raw_json.fitSummary: Blueprint authors of the World Bank’s infrastructure sharing toolkit and multiple national rollouts.
fitPros: Co-authored the global reference manual in Fostering cross-sector infrastructure sharing for broadband, complete with contractual templates.
Implemented shared-fiber backhaul in Enabling Africa’s first end-to-end fiber-to-the-tower backhaul, coordinating utility and mobile operator incentives.
fitCons: Needs alignment with energy and transport ministries in Liberia; we will allocate extra senior time to stakeholder diplomacy.

referenceProjects.title: Fostering cross-sector infrastructure sharing for broadband
referenceProjects.summary: Acting for the World Bank, we developed a web-based resource for telecom operators, utilities, policymakers, regulators and development banks to increase the incidence of cross-sector infrastructure sharing and improve the viability of broadband investments. The toolkit includes 18 case studies from Africa, the Americas, Asia and Europe on telecom use of electric facilities, railways, pipelines and roads.

referenceProjects.title: Enabling Africa’s first end-to-end fiber-to-the-tower backhaul
referenceProjects.summary: State-owned Lesotho Electricity Company had built a fiber network on its transmission lines and had distribution poles throughout its service territory. We advised the utility in selling dark fiber IRUs to Vodacom Lesotho and authorizing the operator to install fiber on distribution poles from substations to towers. This enabled Africa’s first end-to-end fiber-to-the-tower backhaul for a 4G network.

documents.title: Fostering cross-sector infrastructure sharing for broadband

title: Cold Chain Logistics Support for Vaccine Distribution in Uganda

semanticMatches.sourceTitle: Bangalink Briefing Paper To Bb 161004

raw_json.fitSummary: Team has engineered large-scale public-private partnerships and payment rails that underpin vaccine and health logistics across East and West Africa.
fitPros: Designed the settlement reforms in Solving Kenya’s USSD pricing problem for digital financial services, unlocking real-time pricing visibility across mobile channels.
Structured multi-party infrastructure agreements in Introducing innovative national PPPs for West African submarine cable, coordinating operators and governments.
fitCons: Requires rapid mobilisation of cold-chain field partners in Uganda to complement our policy bench.

referenceProjects.title: Solving Kenya’s USSD pricing problem for digital financial services
referenceProjects.summary: Safaricom’s M-Pesa is a World and Kenyan market leader in mobile money. Working with Acacia Economics, we carried out a market inquiry for the Competition Authority of Kenya (CAK) into use of USSD channels for digital financial services. referenceProjects.title: Introducing innovative national PPPs for West African submarine cable
referenceProjects.summary: The World Bank financed development of public private partnerships (PPPs) in West Africa to serve as landing parties for the ACE submarine cable. Acting for the Bank, we introduced a not-for-profit cooperative (shared cost center) institutional design. Our model was adopted by network operators and governments in nine West African countries. We also acted for the Governments of the Gambia, Liberia and Sierra Leone in implementing the model.

title: Supply Chain Optimization Advisory for Essential Medicines in Côte d’Ivoire

semanticMatches.sourceTitle: Competition dynamics in mobile money markets in Tanzania

raw_json.fitSummary: Our economists routinely unwind market bottlenecks and design incentives that keep critical goods moving.
fitPros: Removed entrenched market power in Breaking monopoly bottlenecks for IP transit in landlocked Malawi, delivering 90%+ price reductions for essential connectivity.
Mapped end-to-end user pricing and compliance flows in Studying digital remittances from Malaysia to Philippines—a playbook for transparent supply logistics.
fitCons: Engagement would benefit from in-country data analysts embedded with the Ministry of Health in Côte d’Ivoire.

referenceProjects.title: Breaking monopoly bottlenecks for IP transit in landlocked Malawi
referenceProjects.summary: Landlocked Malawi had only one international fiber route, controlled by dominant operators in two countries, to connect to the Internet. The Public-Private Partnership Commission hired us to employ an anchor-customer business model funded by the World Bank to foster route and supplier diversity. Kenyan firm SimbaNET was selected to build two new routes. The project brought the price of IP transit in Malawi down from USD 3,000/Mbps/month to USD 135 in 2016 and to USD 30 in 2022.

referenceProjects.title: Studying digital remittances from Malaysia to Philippines
referenceProjects.summary: Consultative Group to Assist the Poor (CGAP), a part of the World Bank Group, engaged us to study the regulatory conditions that have enabled the proliferation of remittance services across the Malaysia-Philippines corridor. Our findings include 10 recommendations for policymakers and regulators in other jurisdictions to promote development of non-bank remittance markets.

title: Data Protection and Privacy Regulatory Support for Namibia

semanticMatches.sourceTitle: Big Data, Machine Learning, Consumer Protection and Privacy

raw_json.fitSummary: Combines legislative drafting with hands-on implementation support for regulators standing up new DPAs.
fitPros: Drafted the flagship legislation in Drafting Malawi’s Data Protection Bill with pragmatic supervisory workflows.
Guided multinational IoT deployments in Advising on connected cars, IoT and other digital services, ensuring cross-border compliance.
fitCons: Need to scope localisation requirements in Namibia to anticipate adequacy conversations.

referenceProjects.title: Drafting Malawi’s Data Protection Bill
referenceProjects.summary: The Government of Malawi engaged us to draft their data protection bill. We wove international best practice together with the realities of a low-income economy. We drafted a practical law that would support confidence in and limit the burden on the emerging digital economy. semanticMatches.sourceTitle: Bangalink Briefing Paper To Bb 161004

raw_json.fitSummary: Team has engineered large-scale public-private partnerships and payment rails that underpin vaccine and health logistics across East and West Africa.
fitPros: Designed the settlement reforms in Solving Kenya’s USSD pricing problem for digital financial services, unlocking real-time pricing visibility across mobile channels.
Structured multi-party infrastructure agreements in Introducing innovative national PPPs for West African submarine cable, coordinating operators and governments.
fitCons: Requires rapid mobilisation of cold-chain field partners in Ethiopia to complement our policy bench.

referenceProjects.title: Solving Kenya’s USSD pricing problem for digital financial services
referenceProjects.summary: Safaricom’s M-Pesa is a World and Kenyan market leader in mobile money. Working with Acacia Economics, we carried out a market inquiry for the Competition Authority of Kenya (CAK) into use of USSD channels for digital financial services. Our report found that Safaricom’s high USSD prices caused a margin squeeze for other digital financial service providers. With our support, the CAK negotiated a settlement with Safaricom under which it dropped its USSD prices by 90%, removing a vital barrier to competition in Kenyan digital financial services.

referenceProjects.title: Introducing innovative national PPPs for West African submarine cable
referenceProjects.summary: The World Bank financed development of public private partnerships (PPPs) in West Africa to serve as landing parties for the ACE submarine cable. Acting for the Bank, we introduced a not-for-profit cooperative (shared cost center) institutional design. Our model was adopted by network operators and governments in nine West African countries. We also acted for the Governments of the Gambia, Liberia and Sierra Leone in implementing the model.

title: Infrastructure Sharing Roadmap for Lesotho

semanticMatches.sourceTitle: Fostering cross-sector infrastructure sharing for broadband

raw_json.fitSummary: Blueprint authors of the World Bank’s infrastructure sharing toolkit and multiple national rollouts.
fitPros: Co-authored the global reference manual in Fostering cross-sector infrastructure sharing for broadband, complete with contractual templates.
Implemented shared-fiber backhaul in Enabling Africa’s first end-to-end fiber-to-the-tower backhaul, coordinating utility and mobile operator incentives.
fitCons: Needs alignment with energy and transport ministries in Lesotho; we will allocate extra senior time to stakeholder diplomacy.

referenceProjects.title: Fostering cross-sector infrastructure sharing for broadband
referenceProjects.summary: Acting for the World Bank, we developed a web-based resource for telecom operators, utilities, policymakers, regulators and development banks to increase the incidence of cross-sector infrastructure sharing and improve the viability of broadband investments. The toolkit includes 18 case studies from Africa, the Americas, Asia and Europe on telecom use of electric facilities, railways, pipelines and roads.

referenceProjects.title: Enabling Africa’s first end-to-end fiber-to-the-tower backhaul
referenceProjects.summary: State-owned Lesotho Electricity Company had built a fiber network on its transmission lines and had distribution poles throughout its service territory. We advised the utility in selling dark fiber IRUs to Vodacom Lesotho and authorizing the operator to install fiber on distribution poles from substations to towers. This enabled Africa’s first end-to-end fiber-to-the-tower backhaul for a 4G network.

documents.title: Fostering cross-sector infrastructure sharing for broadband

title: Supply Chain Optimization Advisory for Essential Medicines in Ghana

semanticMatches.sourceTitle: Competition dynamics in mobile money markets in Tanzania

raw_json.fitSummary: Our economists routinely unwind market bottlenecks and design incentives that keep critical goods moving.
fitPros: Removed entrenched market power in Breaking monopoly bottlenecks for IP transit in landlocked Malawi, delivering 90%+ price reductions for essential connectivity.
Mapped end-to-end user pricing and compliance flows in Studying digital remittances from Malaysia to Philippines—a playbook for transparent supply logistics.
fitCons: Engagement would benefit from in-country data analysts embedded with the Ministry of Health in Ghana.

referenceProjects.title: Breaking monopoly bottlenecks for IP transit in landlocked Malawi
referenceProjects.summary: Landlocked Malawi had only one international fiber route, controlled by dominant operators in two countries, to connect to the Internet. The Public-Private Partnership Commission hired us to employ an anchor-customer business model funded by the World Bank to foster route and supplier diversity. Kenyan firm SimbaNET was selected to build two new routes. The project brought the price of IP transit in Malawi down from USD 3,000/Mbps/month to USD 135 in 2016 and to USD 30 in 2022.

referenceProjects.title: Studying digital remittances from Malaysia to Philippines
referenceProjects.summary: Consultative Group to Assist the Poor (CGAP), a part of the World Bank Group, engaged us to study the regulatory conditions that have enabled the proliferation of remittance services across the Malaysia-Philippines corridor. Our findings include 10 recommendations for policymakers and regulators in other jurisdictions to promote development of non-bank remittance markets.

referenceProjects.title: Breaking monopoly bottlenecks for IP transit in landlocked Malawi
referenceProjects.summary: Landlocked Malawi had only one international fiber route, controlled by dominant operators in two countries, to connect to the Internet. title: Cold Chain Logistics Support for Vaccine Distribution in Rwanda

semanticMatches.sourceTitle: Bangalink Briefing Paper To Bb 161004

raw_json.fitSummary: Team has engineered large-scale public-private partnerships and payment rails that underpin vaccine and health logistics across East and West Africa.
fitPros: Designed the settlement reforms in Solving Kenya’s USSD pricing problem for digital financial services, unlocking real-time pricing visibility across mobile channels.
Structured multi-party infrastructure agreements in Introducing innovative national PPPs for West African submarine cable, coordinating operators and governments.
fitCons: Requires rapid mobilisation of cold-chain field partners in Rwanda to complement our policy bench.

referenceProjects.title: Solving Kenya’s USSD pricing problem for digital financial services
referenceProjects.summary: Safaricom’s M-Pesa is a World and Kenyan market leader in mobile money. Working with Acacia Economics, we carried out a market inquiry for the Competition Authority of Kenya (CAK) into use of USSD channels for digital financial services. Our report found that Safaricom’s high USSD prices caused a margin squeeze for other digital financial service providers. With our support, the CAK negotiated a settlement with Safaricom under which it dropped its USSD prices by 90%, removing a vital barrier to competition in Kenyan digital financial services.

referenceProjects.title: Introducing innovative national PPPs for West African submarine cable
referenceProjects.summary: The World Bank financed development of public private partnerships (PPPs) in West Africa to serve as landing parties for the ACE submarine cable. Acting for the Bank, we introduced a not-for-profit cooperative (shared cost center) institutional design. Our model was adopted by network operators and governments in nine West African countries. We also acted for the Governments of the Gambia, Liberia and Sierra Leone in implementing the model.

documents.title: Bangalink Briefing Paper To Bb 161004

title: Infrastructure Sharing Roadmap for Lesotho

semanticMatches.sourceTitle: Fostering cross-sector infrastructure sharing for broadband

raw_json.fitSummary: Blueprint authors of the World Bank’s infrastructure sharing toolkit and multiple national rollouts.
fitPros: Co-authored the global reference manual in Fostering cross-sector infrastructure sharing for broadband, complete with contractual templates.
Implemented shared-fiber backhaul in Enabling Africa’s first end-to-end fiber-to-the-tower backhaul, coordinating utility and mobile operator incentives.
fitCons: Needs alignment with energy and transport ministries in Lesotho; we will allocate extra senior time to stakeholder diplomacy.

referenceProjects.title: Fostering cross-sector infrastructure sharing for broadband
referenceProjects.summary: Acting for the World Bank, we developed a web-based resource for telecom operators, utilities, policymakers, regulators and development banks to increase the incidence of cross-sector infrastructure sharing and improve the viability of broadband investments. The toolkit includes 18 case studies from Africa, the Americas, Asia and Europe on telecom use of electric facilities, railways, pipelines and roads.

referenceProjects.title: Enabling Africa’s first end-to-end fiber-to-the-tower backhaul
referenceProjects.summary: State-owned Lesotho Electricity Company had built a fiber network on its transmission lines and had distribution poles throughout its service territory. We advised the utility in selling dark fiber IRUs to Vodacom Lesotho and authorizing the operator to install fiber on distribution poles from substations to towers. This enabled Africa’s first end-to-end fiber-to-the-tower backhaul for a 4G network.
